titleStmt.title: Nicholas Thorne versus John Goodrich, executor of the last will and testament of Robert Thorne the elder. Bill of complaint by Nicholas Thorne. 1533 - 1538

abstract.p: A bill of complaint by Nicholas Thorne against John Goodrich, executor of the last will and testament of Robert Thorne the elder.

div.p:
Too the right honorable Syr Thomas Audeley
knyght lorde Chauncelour of England

In moste humble wise Shewithe and Complaynythe unto yor good lordship yor daily Orataire Nicholas Thorne
That where oon Robart Thorn late ffather unto yor said Orator beinge in his lyve A man of great substans in
goodes and ryches made constituted and ordeynyd one John Gooderych Clerk parson of the churche of [Christ]church in
Bristowe Executor of his laste will and testament and dyed after whos deathe there came goodes ryches and substances
and Riches of the said Testa[ament] in life to thandes of the said Executor Amountyng to agrett somme of money sufficyent
and alle to paye and satysfy [all] suche dettes and legacies as the said Testor then yn his lyffe ought and above at
the tyme of whos deathe one [Robert Thorne] one of the sonnes of the said Testator also decessed was Indettyd unto hys
said late ffather in the Somme of C Xvj li sterlinge uppon thaccompte or remynyge betwene them dependyng of the surplusage
of wiche goodes over and Above all dettes and legaci[ies] paide and all other charges born and sustaynyd the sayd
Executor purchassed of landes and Tenementes within the said towne of Brystowe as moche as Amountyd to the yerely
Somme of vj li to him and to his heires after wiche purchasse thies had Commycacyon communication was had and ynoied enjoyed?
betwene yor said Orator the said Robart Thorne his brother on the one partie and the said Goderyche on the other
parte cocernynge the makinge establesshinge and contynuewynge of A ffree Scole to be had and kepte within
the seid towne of Brystowe uppon the wcwwhich commycacyon the said Goderyche Covenantyd and agreyd wtwith yor said
Orator and his saide Brother that yff the said Robart Thorne the yeonger wold Expend laye enter and paye
the Somme of A CXvj li that he ought unto his said ffather at the tyme his dethe and also paye CC li of
sterling money of his owne goodes towardes the purchasinge of sertein landes for the said ffree Scoole to be kepte and
contyneuyd in A place called the Barthe att Brystowe aforesaid and to buyld the same That then nott
only the said landes and tenementes of the said yerely valewe of vj li by him purchased withe the goodes and
money of the said Testator shuld be assuryd for the mayntenance and contynuance of the said ffree
Scoole but alsoo suche money and goodes as remayn in thandes of the said Goderyche unadministred
should be expendyd and payde towardes the buyldinge and meintenance of the said Scoole wiche Somme of a Cxvj li
and also the said Somme of CC li the said Robart Thorn the sonne and his assignes after the dethe
of the sayd Robert Thorne the ffather not only have payde but also the executors of the said Robert
Thorn the Sonne after the dethe of the said Robart have payde the Somme of CCC li for thestablish
mente and contynuaunce of the said Scoole And wiche Scoole ys establyshed And ffoundyd And
Soo it is Right honorable lorde that yor said Orator hathe dyvers and many tymes requryed the
Said Sir John Gooderyche to Accomplishe his promyse and Covenant that ys to saye to make sure the
said landes and tenementes of the said valew of vj li by him purchaysed as it afore sayd unto
the said Scoole for the mayntenance of suche chargys as ?use uppon the same wcwich he utterly
denyethe contrary to all right and good consience In ?tender consideracyon wherof hit maye plese yor
good lordship to graunt A writt of sub pena to be dyrectyd unto the said John Godriche commanding him
by vertue therof personally to appere before yor good lordship in the kinges Court of Chauncery at A serten
daye and under a serten payne by yor good lordship to be lymytyd And there to Answere to the primisses And
further to stand to such order and dyreccyon on as shalbe thought best by yor good lordship in that behalf
And yor said Orator shall dayly praye for the longe preservacyon of yor good lordship
